summary: D. J. Brennan, Jr. is mentioned in four documents related to CIA and FBI activities. One memo is addressed to him from S.J. Papich regarding a CIA operation to create a fake U.S.-based communist organization. He is also mentioned in documents concerning CIA relations with the FBI, investigations into individuals, and requests for information related to CIA activities. Another memo discusses the handling of sensitive information received from the CIA, particularly concerning "Bureau Informant 100" (James Angleton) and SCOPE material. Finally, he is mentioned in a document involving coordination between the CIA and FBI regarding the release of JFK assassination-related documents.
significance: D. J. Brennan, Jr.'s significance in the JFK context appears to be related to his involvement in the coordination between the CIA and FBI regarding the release of JFK assassination-related documents. The documents suggest he was involved in discussions about protecting the identities of informants and Soviet agents during the document release process.
